problems.description: Implement the basic Quick Sort algorithm to sort an array in ascending order. Select a pivot element (use the last element), partition the array so smaller elements are left of pivot and larger elements are right of pivot, then recursively sort both partitions. Example: [2,5,1,15,22,19,100,81,70,149] should become [1,2,5,15,19,22,70,81,100,149]. Only JavaScript is allowed.
problems.inputs description: Input consists of an array of unsorted integers. The array may be of arbitrary length.
problems.expected description: A sorted array in ascending order, e.g., [1, 2, 4, 5]

problems.problem name: Optimized Quick Sort with Median of Three
problems.description: Implement Quick Sort using median-of-three pivot selection for better performance. Find the median of the first, middle, and last elements to use as pivot. This prevents O(nÂ²) worst-case performance on sorted arrays and handles duplicates efficiently. Example: [4,7,2,1,5,2,6,8,9,5] should become [1,2,2,4,5,5,6,7,8,9]. Only JavaScript is allowed.
problems.inputs description: Input consists of an array of integers which may contain duplicate values.
problems.expected description: A sorted array in ascending order with duplicates properly positioned.

problems.description: Implement Quick Sort using an iterative approach with a stack instead of recursion. Use a stack to store start and end indices of sub-arrays to avoid recursive calls and prevent stack overflow on large datasets. Push initial bounds (0, array.length-1) to stack, then repeatedly pop bounds, partition the sub-array, and push new bounds until stack is empty. Example: [7,2,9,1,5,6,3,8,4] should become [1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9]. Only JavaScript is allowed.
problems.inputs description: Input consists of an array of integers to be sorted using iterative quick sort.
problems.expected description: The sorted array in ascending order, achieved using in-place quick sort with a stack.
